description: From Middle English gris, from Old Norse gríss.

entries.meaning: (now Scotland) A pig, especially a young pig, or its meat; sometimes specifically, a breed of wild pig or boar native to Scotland, now extinct.
examples: This fine Smooth bawson cub, the young grice of a gray

description: Unknown, possibly from Richard Grice, the first champion trainspotter[2], alternatively perhaps a humorous representation of an upper-class pronunciation of grouser (“grouse-shooter”)[3]. In either case the derivation could be direct or a back-formation from gricer.

verbs.description: grice (third-person singular simple present grices, present participle gricing, simple past and past participle griced)

entries.meaning: (UK, rail transport, slang) to act as a trainspotter; to partake in the activity or hobby of trainspotting.
